infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian

Class TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian.TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, TransferEntropyCalculator, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    public class TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian
extends TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
implements AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    Computes the differential transfer entropy (TE) between two univariate double[] time-series of observations (implementing TransferEntropyCalculator), assuming that the probability distribution function for these observations is a multivariate Gaussian distribution. TE was defined by Schreiber, and Kaiser and Schreiber showed how to compute it via this Gaussian assumption. This estimator is realised here by plugging in ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian as the calculator into the parent class TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.

    That is, this class implements a TE calculator using model of Gaussian variables with linear interactions, making it equivalent (up to a multiplicative constant) to the Granger causality (see Barnett et al below).

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for TransferEntropyCalculator, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian().
    • TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.setProperty(String, String) allowing properties defined for both TransferEntropyCalculator.setProperty(String, String) and ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setProperty(String, String) as outlined in TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.setProperty(String, String)).
    • The user can call setCovariance(double[][], int) instead of supplying observations via TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.setObservations(double[], double[]) or TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.addObservations(double[], double[]) etc.
    • Computed values are in nats, not bits!
    • Additional method computeSignificance() to compute null distribution analytically.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • L. Barnett, A. B. Barrett, A. K. Seth, "Granger Causality and Transfer Entropy Are Equivalent for Gaussian Variables", Physical Review Letters 103 (23) 238701, 2009;
    • A. Kaiser, T. Schreiber, "Information transfer in continuous processes", Physica D, Vol. 166, No. 1-2., pp. 43-62 (2002).
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
    See Also:
    Differential entropy for Gaussian random variables at Mathworld, Differential entropy for Gaussian random variables at Wikipedia, Multivariate normal distribution on Wikipedia, TransferEntropyCalculator, ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian

    • Method Detail

      • setCovariance

        public void setCovariance(double[][] covariance,
                 int numObservations)
                   throws java.lang.Exception

        Set the joint covariance of the distribution for which we will compute the transfer entropy.

        Note that without setting any observations, you cannot later call TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.computeLocalOfPreviousObservations(), and without providing the means of the variables, you cannot later call #computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][]).

        Parameters:
        covariance - joint covariance matrix of source, dest, dest history variables, considered together.
        numObservations - the number of observations that the covariance was determined from. This is used for later significance calculations
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for covariance matrix not matching the expected dimensions, being non-square, asymmetric or non-positive definite

      • computeSignificance

        public ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance()
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate an analytic distribution of what the TE would look like, under a null hypothesis that our variables had no relation (in the context of the conditional value). This is performed without bootstrapping (which is done in #computeSignificance(int, int) and #computeSignificance(int, int[][])). The method is implemented using the corresponding method of the underlying ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below, and the other papers referenced in AnalyticNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance() (in particular Geweke), for a description of how this is done for TE and conditional MI. Basically, the null distribution is a chi-square distribution.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Returns:
        ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution object which describes the proportion of TE scores from the null distribution which have higher or equal conditional MIs to our actual value.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian#computeSignificance()}, "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • getDeterminants

        public double[] getDeterminants()
        Debug method to check the computed determinants
        Returns:
        an array of the four relevant determinants computed by the underlying ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian: of the whole covariance matrix, of the source and conditionals, of the destination and conditionals, and of the conditionals themselves.
